unnormalised: **Project Tiger Expansion Bolsters Conservation Efforts in the Sunderbans**
normalised: Project Tiger Expansion Bolsters Conservation Efforts in the Sunderbans

unnormalised: Kolkata, West Bengal - Recent expansions to the Project Tiger reserve in the Sunderbans are yielding positive results for the critically endangered Bengal tiger population. Dr. Anya Sharma, Director of the Wildlife Institute of India, reported a 15% increase in tiger sightings within the expanded zone in the last quarter.
normalised: Kolkata, West Bengal - Recent expansions to the Project Tiger reserve in the Sunderbans are yielding positive results for the critically endangered Bengal tiger population. Doctor Anya Sharma, Director of the Wildlife Institute of India, reported a fifteen percent increase in tiger sightings within the expanded zone in the last quarter.

unnormalised: The project, funded by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change with an allocation of Rs. 50 crores, focuses on habitat restoration and anti-poaching measures. This includes clearing invasive species from approximately 20,000 sq ft of the mangrove forest and installing advanced surveillance equipment.
normalised: The project, funded by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change with an allocation of rupees fifty crores, focuses on habitat restoration and anti-poaching measures. This includes clearing invasive species from approximately twenty thousand square feet of the mangrove forest and installing advanced surveillance equipment.

unnormalised: "Community involvement is key," stated Mr. Banerjee, a local forest officer. "We are working with local villages to promote sustainable livelihoods and reduce human-animal conflict." The expansion, covering an additional 50 km, aims to provide a wider roaming area for tigers and protect their prey base, including the chital deer and wild boar. Conservationists hope that these efforts will further enhance the biodiversity of this crucial ecosystem and safeguard the iconic Royal Bengal tiger for future generations.
normalised: "Community involvement is key," stated Mister Banerjee, a local forest officer. "We are working with local villages to promote sustainable livelihoods and reduce human-animal conflict." The expansion, covering an additional fifty kilometer, aims to provide a wider roaming area for tigers and protect their prey base, including the chital deer and wild boar. Conservationists hope that these efforts will further enhance the biodiversity of this crucial ecosystem and safeguard the iconic Royal Bengal tiger for future generations.
